Phar Mate

My team and I were tasked with building an interactive point-of-sale kiosk prototype. We leveraged online research to inform our ideas, storyboards, wireframes, and physical prototype.

The PharMate kiosk-locker setup is meant to coexist with, not fully replace, traditional in-person pickup. This is because, at least from our data and experience, people may prefer interacting with a real person instead of a machine; for others, the opposite is true. The idea is that with the divide between the traditional pharmacy line, the kiosk line, and the mobile app, wait times would be reduced overall.

Roles: Researcher, visual designer

Skills: Needfinding, user interviews, storyboarding, wireframing, rapid prototyping, physical prototyping, visual design

Date: Jan - Mar 2019 (10 weeks)

Teammates: Madeline Ng, Lam Pham, Julie Fung, Allie Pai

Secondary Research

We conducted online research and looked to other competitors that had POS kiosks in a medical or pharmacy context for inspiration and how we can better employ existing solutions in the current market.

Personas + Storyboards

We also looked at pharmacy and drug use cases to inform our personas. We made personas for a range of people that the kiosk could cater to, from people dealing with addiction to disabled persons. We decided to emphasize two personas: one that had needs for general efficiency of use and another that required an intuitive design and foreign language support.

Paper Prototypes

We did some rapid prototyping and tests on a simple purchase flow, where users had to have the kiosk identify them and then have them pay for their prescription medicine. We had 1 note-taker and 1 facilitator while the rest of our group watched. We learned that prototype required more signifiers as to when a task was completed. Due to a lack of visual or auditory feedback, the user reached the payment stage and was confused that his ID was still in the card reader. In this case, we decided to have two card readers, one for identity and the other for payment.

User Interviews

We interviewed people who have used any form of POS kiosk but tried to mostly interview people who used medical ones. We asked them questions on their general experience and pain points associated with the specific kiosk experience they used. Below are some of the more notable notes:

  • Something the interviewees liked about the ATM was how in order to get the cash, you have pull out your credit/debit card before the door for cash opens. This ensures that the user wouldn’t forget his/her card.
  • In one of the interviewee’s experiences with CVS pharmacy, she mentioned how you can opt to wait in the store or pick up the medication later with a confirmation text. However, when she chose to wait in the store, there was no signifier/feedback to let her know that her medication was ready.
  • Another interviewee mentioned that she does not need to wait in heavy lines at the pharmacy when she is picking up her birth control prescription because her app tells her exactly when to pick it up. Although birth control is covered by her insurance she mentioned that she has the ability to pay on the app which she finds convenient. She also likes that she does not need to interact with the pharmacist or have to call for confirmation which speeds up the process of getting her prescriptions. Many interviewees also preferred the locker pick up as opposed to a vending machine pickup because the lockers would provide more security.

Wireframes

View full wireframe screens here.

Moodboard + Style Guide

Final Crit

From the feedback in our crit, we decided to add a time delay between the moment you get the receipt and when you pick it up, much like the QR code portion of our prototype. This is because there needs to be some delay for someone to put medicine in the locker and for privacy demanded in today's kiosk technologies (e.g. Amazon Locker). We also rearranged the physical elements on our initial prototype to make it look less cluttered, a comment we received in usability tests.

Final Clickable Prototype

Changes we made to our clickable prototypes based on usability testing involved: providing more audio or visual feedback to some screens to indicate the conclusion of a task or to prompt user to proceed, changing wording and prices to reflect real world ones, and creating an app version to separate the QR code process/preorder process from the in-person purchase process.

View the full kiosk prototype screens here.

View the full mobile kiosk prototype screens here.

Post Mortem

If we were to make further changes we would probably be investing more time and money into creating a high-fidelity prototype with better craft. Rather than using cardboard, perhaps we would consider using more durable material such as metal sheets or wood, anything that would resemble an actual kiosk. We would also consider installing LED lights for the lockers rather than using the Wizard of Oz method. Spray paint instead of regular paint (which is more suitable for art) would be appropriate in giving off a professional and sterile look.
